Detailed Description

Access to global data.

An object of class Access represents link accesses to shared variable. Each access to a shared data is implemented by an Access object. A closure that has multiple accesses to a shared data has multiple Access objects associated to it. See ClosureFormat and Closure class. An access object has a state:

  • ready: (bit0) == 1 iff the access is ready, it means that previous access are finished or the previous access is ready and it is concurrent with the access.
  • mode : (bit1-4) it is the AccessMode::val as previously defined.
  • stack/heap: bit 5 == 1 (32) if the read data is in a stack else it is in heap
  • sticky: bit 6 (96) if the read data is sticky
  • stack/heap: bit 7 == 1 (128) if the write data is in a stack else it is in heap
  • sticky: bit 8 (256) if the write data is sticky

The fields _X_version represents either the version to read or the version to write. If the _X_version fields are set to zero then the data referenced by the global data are used. Both _r_version and _w_version and gd->_data are assumed to be of the same format.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum DFG::Access::Flag

Flag of the memory location of the local data Note that this flags are exclusive and are shifted to the 5 or 7 depending on the version to consider (read or write).

Enumerator:
IN_HEAP 
IN_STACK 
STICKY 

Member Function Documentation

void DFG::Access::advance_version (  ) 

Advance the version to the next access This method is called to signal that the current access is ready and the data may be propagate to the next access. Both theft thread and TaskSignal invoke this method to propagate the state of the access to the next access.

void DFG::Access::release_version (  )  [inline]

Release the access The method should be invoked when task releases its access to data. The access is ready because the task has been executed. The readiness is forwarded to the next access in the chain. If the next access already contains an other version, then the associated version is deleted according to the memory mapping rules of the version. This method is generally invoked by the thread that executes the closure.

void DFG::Access::release_version_2 (  )
